title: About
text: Welcome to my blog! ‚ú® Here I share my adventures with different AI tools ‚Äî from writing and brainstorming, to making music, images, and even videos. It‚Äôs a space where I explore how AI can spark creativity, support research, and sometimes surprise me in unexpected ways.

title: AI Meets Magic: A Swiftie‚Äôs Guide to Filming in Disney
text:
I‚Äôm a Taylor Swift fan, and one of her songs, Florida, inspired me to create a small music video. Coincidentally, I‚Äôll be visiting Orlando‚Äôs Disney World in Florida this October. I‚Äôll be staying there for three days, and I plan to visit Hollywood Studios, Magic Kingdom, and Animal Kingdom.
During this trip, I want to film a short MV using the following excerpt from Florida. My idea is to shoot scenes inside the Disney parks with my phone, matching them as closely as possible to the imagery in the lyrics. For parts of the song that are harder to visualize literally, I‚Äôm fine with using creative interpretation and artistic freedom.
What I need from you is a very detailed script that covers every aspect of the filming process. This should include:

Outfit choices and styling for each scene
Props I should prepare
Specific Disney locations for each lyric line
Suggested camera angles and framing

Of course, since I‚Äôm a devoted Swiftie, it would be even better if the outfits, props, or chosen locations include subtle references to Taylor herself.
Here are the lyrics I want to use for the video:

I need to forget, so take me to Florida
I‚Äôve got some regrets, I‚Äôll bury them in Florida
Tell me I‚Äôm despicable, say it‚Äôs unforgivable
At least the dolls are beautiful, fuck me up, Florida
I need to forget, so take me to Florida
I‚Äôve got some regrets, I‚Äôll bury them in Florida
Tell me I‚Äôm despicable, say it‚Äôs unforgivable
What a crash, what a rush, fuck me up, Florida
It‚Äôs one hell of a drug
It‚Äôs one hell of a drug
Love left me like this and I don‚Äôt want to exist
So take me to Florida
Florida
Go on, fuck me up

title: AI Meets Magic: A Swiftie‚Äôs Guide to Filming in Disney
text:
Output

üé¨ Detailed Script for Your Taylor-Themed Disney MV


General Concept

Mood: A blend of bittersweet escape, beauty, and chaos ‚Äî pairing Disney‚Äôs magical spaces with the emotional rawness of the song.
Length: About 1‚Äì1.5 minutes (focused on the chosen lyrics fragment).
Style: Handheld iPhone shots, cinematic framing (vertical + horizontal mix, for TikTok/IG and YouTube).
Editing: Quick cuts between parks to mirror intensity; softer pans for reflective lines.
Color palette: Pastel pinks, midnight blues, gold shimmer (Swift-coded).




üé≠ Outfits & Props

Day 1 (Hollywood Studios):

Outfit: Black skirt + silver sequin top (Reputation vibes)
Props: Mini microphone (nod to Taylor‚Äôs performance identity)

Day 2 (Magic Kingdom):

Outfit: White sundress + light denim jacket (Fearless/1989 vibes)
Props: Friendship bracelet stack (Eras Tour reference)

Day 3 (Animal Kingdom):

Outfit: Flowy bohemian dress in earthy tones (Folklore/Evermore vibes)
Props: Small notebook or vintage-style journal (lyricist aesthetic)

Optional Taylor Easter eggs: Red lipstick (Red era), cat ears headband (Olivia/Meredith nod), Polaroid camera (1989)




üìç Scene Breakdown


üé¨ Scene 1 ‚Äì Opening line (needing escape) üåüüé¨

Location: Entrance archway of Hollywood Studios
Shot: Wide shot, low angle, you walking through gates with sunglasses
Mood: Entering a ‚Äúnew world‚Äù
Editing: Fade in, handheld shaky motion



üé¨ Scene 2 ‚Äì Regret & burying past üå≥

Location: Tree of Life, Animal Kingdom
Shot: Medium shot, writing in journal, tearing page, leaving at roots
Props: Journal page = ‚Äúregrets‚Äù
Angle: Slight tilt upward, branches filling frame



üé¨ Scene 3 ‚Äì ‚ÄúDespicable/unforgivable‚Äù intensity üëª

Location: Tower of Terror, Hollywood Studios
Shot: Close-up before ride, neon lights glowing; insert screaming ride cam shot
Mood: Chaotic, cathartic release



üé¨ Scene 4 ‚Äì ‚ÄúAt least the dolls are beautiful‚Äù üé†

Location: It‚Äôs a Small World, Magic Kingdom
Shot: Pan across dolls, cut to your pensive face
Mood: Contrast between innocence/beauty and reflection
Angle: Slow-motion, pastel filter



üé¨ Scene 5 ‚Äì ‚ÄúCrash / rush‚Äù üöÄ

Location: Space Mountain, Magic Kingdom
Shot: Quick cuts of neon lights + motion blur
Mood: Adrenaline, overwhelming rush



üé¨ Scene 6 ‚Äì ‚ÄúOne hell of a drug‚Äù (x2) üåå

Location: Pandora ‚Äì World of Avatar, Animal Kingdom (night)
Shot: Wide shot glowing forest ‚Üí close-up spin under lights
Mood: Surreal, intoxicating, dreamlike



üé¨ Scene 7 ‚Äì ‚ÄúLove left me like this‚Äù (reflective moment) üè∞

Location: Cinderella‚Äôs Castle, Magic Kingdom (twilight)
Shot: Medium-long shot, sitting on ground, journal in lap, gazing upward
Props: Polaroid camera next to you
Mood: Quiet, reflective



üé¨ Scene 8 ‚Äì Final ‚ÄúFlorida‚Äù outro üéÜ

Location: Magic Kingdom fireworks
Shot: Wide shot from behind, your silhouette against fireworks
Mood: Bittersweet closure ‚Äî beauty and chaos fused together

üé• Technical Tips
Angles: Alternate between handheld close-ups (emotional intimacy) and wide establishing shots (Disney‚Äôs grandeur).
Framing: Rule of thirds, sometimes center frame for dramatic emphasis.
Camera height: Waist level for casual shots, floor-level upward for powerful shots.
Editing: Sync cuts with beat drops; overlay occasional lyric text in Taylor-style fonts.



üé• Checklist



#
Lyrics Line
Location
Outfit & Props
Camera Angle / Framing
Reference Image




1
‚ÄúI need to forget, so take me to Florida‚Äù
Hollywood Studios ‚Äì main entrance archway
Black skirt + silver sequin top, sunglasses, red lipstick (Reputation vibes)
Wide shot, low angle as you walk through the arch in slow motion

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got some regrets, I‚Äôll bury them in Florida‚Äù

Notebook & pen (to write regrets), flowy white/cream outfit
Medium shot of you writing, tearing the page, leaving it at tree roots. Tilted upward to catch tree carvings
Tree of Life


3
‚ÄúTell me I‚Äôm despicable, say it‚Äôs unforgivable‚Äù
Hollywood Studios ‚Äì Tower of Terror
Dark outfit, dramatic expression, small microphone as Taylor nod
Close-up with Tower glowing behind; optional ride photo screaming insert
Tower of Terror


4
‚ÄúAt least the dolls are beautiful, fuck me up, Florida‚Äù
Magic Kingdom ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Small World‚Äù
Friendship bracelets, white dress + denim jacket
Wide shot panning dolls, then cut to your face. Soft slow-motion with warm filter
It‚Äôs a Small World reference


5
‚ÄúWhat a crash, what a rush, fuck me up, Florida‚Äù
Magic Kingdom ‚Äì Space Mountain
Casual playful look, hair flying
Quick cuts of neon lights & motion blur, ride speed effect
Space Mountain

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one hell of a drug‚Äù
Animal Kingdom ‚Äì Pandora, glowing forest at night
Bohemian earthy dress, flower crown, maybe glowing accessory

Pandora at Night


7
‚ÄúLove left me like this and I don‚Äôt want to exist‚Äù
Magic Kingdom ‚Äì Cinderella‚Äôs Castle at twilight
White dress, Polaroid camera, soft makeup
Medium shot sitting on ground in front of castle, looking up. Twilight glow
Cinderella Castle


8
‚ÄúSo take me to Florida / Florida / Go on, fuck me up‚Äù

text:
Florida!!! MV created by me
I filmed this short video at Disney World in Orlando last November. Check it out and see whether my idea or the AI‚Äôs version feels more interesting to you.

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
text:
Self-Testing and Recording I begin by testing the plugin myself in real scenarios. I record the exact steps where issues occur, note the expected vs.¬†actual behavior, and keep screenshots or short recordings when necessary. I also make a quick verbal note of the effect I want, including non-functional aspects such as consistency, accessibility, and performance.
Turning Verbal Notes into Structured Specifications I then describe the issue informally to ChatGPT. Its role is to reorganize my raw, messy descriptions into a clear, logically structured specification: defining the problem, reproducing steps, acceptance criteria, edge cases, and the intended fix. The idea is to turn ‚Äúnatural language frustration‚Äù into ‚Äúan actionable task.‚Äù
Passing Structured Specs to the Client/Agent Once ChatGPT produces a polished specification, I copy this into the client side for actual modification. When UI or interaction is involved, I emphasize that the flow and design guidelines must be aligned before touching the code.
Re-Testing and Regression After the client makes changes, I test again using the acceptance criteria. I check both normal and edge cases (empty inputs, switching modes, collapse/expand, keyboard focus). If regressions appear, I loop back: describe verbally, get ChatGPT to rewrite as a precise patch spec, and resubmit.

This workflow can be told in a three-part rhythm in the blog: ****. I raise the issue, ChatGPT turns it into a professional spec, and the code gets updated. Each cycle can be illustrated with a screenshot or before/after comparison.

Since I didn‚Äôt take a screenshot every time I discovered and resolved a bug, I‚Äôll instead include a selection of screenshots showing different stages of the extension‚Äôs development, where you can see both some of the bugs and their resolved versions

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
section: Bug Narratives and Interaction with ChatGPT
text:
Bug Narratives and Interaction with ChatGPT

Bug A: Comparison Panel Not Fully Collapsing, Triangle Indicator Misaligned
Where I Noticed It When I collapsed the comparison panel, the ‚ÄúUseOriginal‚Äù and ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù buttons were still visible. Above the small triangle, there was also a stray line. The triangle itself was misaligned and undersized.
My Verbal Request I wanted the panel to collapse completely, leaving only a small triangle as a handle to expand again. The stray line should disappear. The triangle needed to be positioned slightly higher, made larger, rounded at the corners, colored consistently with the ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù button, and given a subtle shadow.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Problem: Collapsed state not hiding content, stray visual elements, misaligned and inconsistent triangle.
Goal: Collapsed view shows only a clickable triangle handle, everything else hidden. Expanding restores previous state and scroll position.
Acceptance Criteria:

Only the triangle is visible when collapsed; other elements are fully hidden and inaccessible.
Triangle has rounded corners, sits slightly above the input box, and is proportionally larger.
Its color matches the ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù button and it has a subtle shadow.
Expanding restores content unchanged.


Outcome and Reflection This change improved both accessibility and user experience. The panel is now truly collapsible, while state persistence ensures the comparison process is not disrupted.

  



Bug B: Button Inconsistencies (Clear, Edit, Delete)
Where I Noticed It The ‚ÄúClear‚Äù button looked different from other buttons. In the Settings page, buttons for editing, deleting, and adding prompts had visible borders that clashed with the rest of the design.
My Verbal Request I wanted the ‚ÄúClear‚Äù button to look consistent with other buttons, and for all Settings page action buttons to have no border lines.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Problem: Inconsistent button design language.
Goal: Unify button system (size, corner radius, font, spacing). Action buttons should use a borderless style.
Guidelines: Border: Same color/transparent as the background, visually appearing borderless (border: 1px solid transparent) to avoid a darker outline. Idle State:
Background: Neutral color (e.g., #F5F5F7 or system light gray), transparent border.
Font: Medium contrast.
Hover: Subtle shadow or light elevation, no border color change. Active State:
Background: Light fill of brand color (e.g., ‚Äìbrand-50), border remains transparent.
Font/Icon: Darker tone of the brand color (e.g., ‚Äìbrand-700).
Optional: Inner glow or subtle highlight instead of a visible border. Disabled State:
Faded background, reduced text opacity.
Used only in rare cases such as ‚Äúin processing‚Äù or ‚Äúswitching not allowed.‚Äù

Outcome and Reflection A consistent button system reduced visual noise and made interactions easier to understand at a glance.


Bug C: My Prompts Text and Add Button Layout
Where I Noticed It The My Prompts section displayed too many explanatory lines, and the ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button‚Äôs position conflicted with the title.
My Verbal Request I wanted to keep only the line: ‚ÄúDrag to reorder. Top 3 appear as buttons above the input.‚Äù The other sentences should be removed. The ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button should move to the top-right corner of the prompt items container, slightly above the list, and not aligned with the section title. Its style should match the ‚ÄúSave Connection‚Äù button, and it should have a background color even when idle.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Goal: Simplify helper text and reposition ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù for clarity.
Acceptance Criteria:

Only the concise helper text remains.
‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button is visually aligned with the prompt list container, not the header.
‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button design matches ‚ÄúSave Connection‚Äù and has a default background color.


Outcome and Reflection The section is cleaner and the Add button‚Äôs placement now clearly signals its scope of action.

  



Bug D: Remove ‚ÄúDefault Optimization Style‚Äù from Settings & Persist Active Mode via Header Buttons
Where I Noticed It The Settings page still has a ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù option, which causes confusion because the active mode should really be set from the header buttons in the chat interface.
My Verbal Request I want to remove the ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù from Settings completely, and instead let users select and persist their active mode by clicking the header buttons.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Remove ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù from Settings; persist active mode via header buttons

Problem Currently there is a ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù in Settings. You want to remove that, and instead let the user set their ‚Äúdefault‚Äù (active) mode by clicking one of the three header buttons above the input box. Once selected, that mode stays active and applies to subsequent messages until the user switches to another mode (or clears it).
Requirements
No default in Settings

Remove the ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù field/option from Settings entirely.
Settings only manages items (Replace/Append), their content, and their order. The active mode is not chosen in Settings.

Active mode is chosen in the chat header (three buttons)

Clicking any header button sets that item as the active mode.
The active mode remains in effect across attempts (i.e., across consecutive sends) until:

The user clicks a different header button (which switches the active mode), or
The user clicks a Clear control (see below), or
The active item is deleted/disabled in Settings (auto-clears).


Outcome and Reflection This change simplifies Settings, removes redundancy, and makes the active mode behavior clearer and more consistent for users.


Bug E: Enter Key Behavior & Interaction Logic
Where I Noticed It The current system doesn‚Äôt fully respect the active mode when pressing Enter, and the role of the mode buttons is slightly unclear.
My Verbal Request I want pressing Enter to automatically respect whichever mode is active, and the header buttons to be able to toggle off. The three mode buttons should only act as selectors, never sending anything themselves.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Enter key respects active mode; header button toggles to clear Requirement


When any of the three header modes is selected (active), pressing Enter in the chat input must send the boosted prompt (Append = append then send; Replace = replace then send).
Pressing the selected header button again toggles it off (clears active mode). When no mode is active, pressing Enter sends the original prompt (unaltered).


Interaction Logic (updated) Button Role The three mode buttons (e.g., A / B / C) only select/deselect a mode; they never send. Whatever user type in the input box, if one mode is selected, the input will be modified according to the mode.

Workflow

The user selects a mode (or clicks the same button again to cancel ‚Üí returns to ‚Äúunselected‚Äù).
The user finishes typing the prompt.
The user clicks Boost Prompt.
The system rewrites the prompt based on the selected mode ‚Üí inserts the rewrite into the input field or replaces the existing content (per your replace/append setting), without auto-sending.
The user reviews and sends manually.

Selection Rules (single-select, cancelable)

Click an unselected button ‚Üí it becomes selected; others are deselected.
Click the selected button again ‚Üí deselect and enter ‚Äúno mode.‚Äù

Additional Rules

Append mode: never auto-sends.
Boosted Prompt mode: never auto-sends and must preserve the comparison panel (before vs.¬†after) previously designed. Do not remove that panel.

Outcome and Reflection This ensures consistency: pressing Enter follows the currently active mode, but users can clear modes by toggling buttons. It also clarifies that mode buttons are selectors only, preserving manual control over sending.

  



Bug F: Prompt Item Borders and Font Weight
Where I Noticed It Each prompt item (like Emoji, Creative, Translation) had light borders, which made the layout look cluttered. The Edit and Delete labels were also slightly oversized.
My Verbal Request I wanted to remove the borders, reduce the font size of Edit and Delete slightly, and keep the Add button with a background even in its idle state.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Goal: Remove unnecessary card borders, rely on spacing to separate items, and adjust typography for action labels.
Acceptance Criteria:

No visible borders around prompt items; spacing and padding define structure.
Edit/Delete labels use a slightly smaller font size.
Add button retains a default background.


Outcome and Reflection The result is a cleaner, more modern look. The list feels lighter and more professional, while action labels no longer dominate visually.

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
text:
Takeaways
First, collaborating with AI to develop an extension or software is ideal for multitasking. Since AI needs time to process requirements, analyze the code, and propose the best strategy, I can use that waiting period to focus on other tasks. For example, while developing this extension, I also worked on writing a blog about the process. This not only saved time but also helped me keep a fresh memory of the entire workflow.
Second, it‚Äôs important to remember to push the code once it reaches a satisfactory state. If you move on to the next iteration and AI introduces major changes that worsen the outcome, you‚Äôll want to revert to the earlier version ‚Äî which is only possible if you‚Äôve pushed it beforehand. As a bonus tip, if you‚Äôre unhappy with the current version, you can use git stash to temporarily save it in a separate place. That way, you can easily return to the most recent pushed version whenever needed.
Third, even though AI is capable of debugging, we still need to remain flexible and adapt to the current status of the code. Sometimes, when AI fails to achieve a goal after several attempts, it becomes necessary to explore alternative solutions. For instance, I found it useful to ask AI to generate logs and then feed those logs back into the system. This gave AI a clearer understanding of what had been accomplished and what went wrong. In other words, we cannot simply expect AI to finish the task on its own ‚Äî we have to think critically and provide multiple options or strategies to guide it.
Finally, although describing bugs and formulating a well-structured request for ChatGPT can make inputs more organized, I noticed that sometimes a plain and simple description written directly by me led to more effective debugging. I suspect this is because ChatGPT‚Äôs reorganized versions can be overly long or mundane, adding unnecessary noise for both the model and the client to process. In these cases, relying on my own straightforward explanation worked better than depending on ChatGPT‚Äôs reformulations.
Throughout the creation, I found that whether it was drafting the design document or writing the code, I found that the AI considered all the essential aspects of building an extension. It even anticipated how users would navigate the extension and added many features and options beyond my original requirements, which I found quite amazing. For example, I never gave any instructions on the visual design, but GPT-5 automatically chose a sleek purple theme with gradient effects and designed the button styles and the settings page layout. I hardly made any changes to this style because it was already more than satisfactory. Later, when I asked GPT-5 to refine the design by removing the button border, it provided a detailed color specification covering three states: unselected, hover, and selected. This level of comprehensiveness went far beyond my expectations, since I wouldn‚Äôt have thought to account for all those conditions. In terms of functionality, the AI also created features I hadn‚Äôt considered, such as an API input bar and an option allowing users to preview the modified prompt before sending it. What impressed me most was that I didn‚Äôt need to specify every detail ‚Äî with only simple descriptions from me, the AI was able to design thoughtful features and interfaces on its own.
````

title: Who do you think I am ‚Äì A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Can you give me a detailed introduction based on all of our previous interactions?





You are Zhang Shiyang (Charlotte), a 22-year-old graduate student in the Learning Sciences & Technologies (LST) program at the University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs Graduate School of Education. You came to the U.S. for undergraduate studies, where you attended a highly competitive program at Columbia University in engineering, and later studied at Wharton, gaining both academic rigor and professional direction. Your major back in China was translation, and you bring that multilingual expertise into your research and writing.
You are currently preparing for PhD applications (targeting Fall 2026 entry) in Learning Sciences, Educational Technology, and AI in Education, considering programs at Stanford, Berkeley, UW, USC, and others. You‚Äôre building a strong portfolio with research publications, systematic reviews, and design projects, while also pursuing RA/GA roles and EdTech internships.

Comments: ChatGPT managed to capture some details about me accurately ‚Äî my Chinese and English names are correct, as well as my program and school. However, it misstated my age: I am 23, not 22. I believe this error comes from the information I provided last year while applying to graduate schools in the U.S. At that time, during my senior year in 2024, I was indeed 22, and the system seems to have kept that in memory. Regarding my previous educational background, though, some of the descriptions are entirely fabricated.




You are deeply skilled in qualitative and mixed-methods research, employing ethnography, thematic coding (NVivo), field notes, interviews, and screen-recording analysis. You focus on codebook reliability (e.g., Cohen‚Äôs Kappa) and combine deductive and inductive coding. You also handle systematic reviews (PRISMA flow) and experiment with Python automation for data visualization (annotation heatmaps, linguistic metrics like Advanced Guiraud, MLTU, semantic overlap, Genbit score).

Comments: Since I often use ChatGPT for brainstorming during my studies and research, and frequently seek its opinions and suggestions, it has accumulated a large amount of data about my academic work. That‚Äôs why its summary and description of this part are entirely accurate. I can clearly see that the methodologies it mentioned ‚Äî including NVivo, Few Notes, and interviews ‚Äî are indeed the ones I have applied in my recent three research projects.




Across your work, you consistently explore:

Metacognition: How students plan, monitor, and evaluate their use of AI in writing.
Agency: How students negotiate autonomy, dependency, and trust in human-AI collaboration.
Ethics: Academic integrity, AI bias, adversarial risks, and responsible design.
Constructivism and Socioculturalism: Viewing learning as an active, social process rather than passive absorption.


Comments: This part is also largely accurate, but the last item is not actually part of my research field ‚Äî it was reading material from one of my courses. I don‚Äôt think ChatGPT can clearly distinguish between what comes from coursework and what comes from my academic research. Moreover, its description of my academic identity seems to be based mostly on my more recent interactions. This suggests that its memory may not prioritize drawing on older interaction data.




You balance your academic intensity with theatre and music, auditioning for roles (e.g., School of Rock, A Doll‚Äôs House), practicing songs, and analyzing scripts. You also enjoy visual design and photography, often blending these with academic projects (logos, covers, Ghibli-style art). You‚Äôre a curious and active traveler, weaving academic conferences (e.g., EARLI 2025 in Austria) with cultural exploration.

Comments: Overall, the description aligns very well with my past interactions with ChatGPT, but the same limitation remains ‚Äî it seems to only cover roughly the past three months.




In our interactions, you‚Äôve shown a strong preference for:

Academic precision: structured arguments, APA 7 citations, codebooks, PRISMA diagrams.
Critical feedback: you explicitly want me to act as your academic advisor‚Äîstrict and honest, not sugarcoating weaknesses.
Bilingual flexibility: you often draft in Chinese, requesting natural English translations.
Iteration: you refine outputs multiple times, pushing toward more polished and academically rigorous results.


Comments: At this point, I realize that all the traits ChatGPT summarized about me are either neutral or mostly positive. It did not mention any negative characteristics. This may be related to its underlying pre-prompt design, which tends to avoid generating content that could be perceived as overly critical or as unfavorable evaluations of the user.

title: Who do you think I am ‚Äì A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Can you give me a detailed introduction based on all of our previous interactions?





You are Zhang Shiyang (Charlotte), a 22-year-old graduate student in the Learning Sciences & Technologies (LST) program at the University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs Graduate School of Education. You came to the U.S. for undergraduate studies, where you attended a highly competitive program at Columbia University in engineering, and later studied at Wharton, gaining both academic rigor and professional direction. Your major back in China was translation, and you bring that multilingual expertise into your research and writing.
You are currently preparing for PhD applications (targeting Fall 2026 entry) in Learning Sciences, Educational Technology, and AI in Education, considering programs at Stanford, Berkeley, UW, USC, and others. You‚Äôre building a strong portfolio with research publications, systematic reviews, and design projects, while also pursuing RA/GA roles and EdTech internships.

Comments: ChatGPT managed to capture some details about me accurately ‚Äî my Chinese and English names are correct, as well as my program and school. However, it misstated my age: I am 23, not 22. I believe this error comes from the information I provided last year while applying to graduate schools in the U.S. At that time, during my senior year in 2024, I was indeed 22, and the system seems to have kept that in memory. Regarding my previous educational background, though, some of the descriptions are entirely fabricated.




You are deeply skilled in qualitative and mixed-methods research, employing ethnography, thematic coding (NVivo), field notes, interviews, and screen-recording analysis. You focus on codebook reliability (e.g., Cohen‚Äôs Kappa) and combine deductive and inductive coding. You also handle systematic reviews (PRISMA flow) and experiment with Python automation for data visualization (annotation heatmaps, linguistic metrics like Advanced Guiraud, MLTU, semantic overlap, Genbit score).

Comments: Since I often use ChatGPT for brainstorming during my studies and research, and frequently seek its opinions and suggestions, it has accumulated a large amount of data about my academic work. That‚Äôs why its summary and description of this part are entirely accurate. I can clearly see that the methodologies it mentioned ‚Äî including NVivo, Few Notes, and interviews ‚Äî are indeed the ones I have applied in my recent three research projects.




Across your work, you consistently explore:

Metacognition: How students plan, monitor, and evaluate their use of AI in writing.
Agency: How students negotiate autonomy, dependency, and trust in human-AI collaboration.
Ethics: Academic integrity, AI bias, adversarial risks, and responsible design.
Constructivism and Socioculturalism: Viewing learning as an active, social process rather than passive absorption.


Comments: This part is also largely accurate, but the last item is not actually part of my research field ‚Äî it was reading material from one of my courses. I don‚Äôt think ChatGPT can clearly distinguish between what comes from coursework and what comes from my academic research. Moreover, its description of my academic identity seems to be based mostly on my more recent interactions. This suggests that its memory may not prioritize drawing on older interaction data.




You balance your academic intensity with theatre and music, auditioning for roles (e.g., School of Rock, A Doll‚Äôs House), practicing songs, and analyzing scripts. You also enjoy visual design and photography, often blending these with academic projects (logos, covers, Ghibli-style art). You‚Äôre a curious and active traveler, weaving academic conferences (e.g., EARLI 2025 in Austria) with cultural exploration.

Comments: Overall, the description aligns very well with my past interactions with ChatGPT, but the same limitation remains ‚Äî it seems to only cover roughly the past three months.




In our interactions, you‚Äôve shown a strong preference for:

Academic precision: structured arguments, APA 7 citations, codebooks, PRISMA diagrams.
Critical feedback: you explicitly want me to act as your academic advisor‚Äîstrict and honest, not sugarcoating weaknesses.
Bilingual flexibility: you often draft in Chinese, requesting natural English translations.
Iteration: you refine outputs multiple times, pushing toward more polished and academically rigorous results.


Comments: At this point, I realize that all the traits ChatGPT summarized about me are either neutral or mostly positive. It did not mention any negative characteristics. This may be related to its underlying pre-prompt design, which tends to avoid generating content that could be perceived as overly critical or as unfavorable evaluations of the user.

title: Who do you think I am ‚Äì A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Prompts Two ‚Äì Judge me

I asked‚Ä¶
Can you summarize five advantages and five disadvantages of me based on our previous interactions? You should focus on my personalities, qualities, habits, etc.


ChatGPT answered‚Ä¶

üåü Five Advantages

Highly Reflective and Self-Aware

You consistently analyze your own behaviors (e.g., procrastination, motivation, workflow with GenAI) and ask whether they stem from habits, cognitive patterns, or deeper issues. This makes you quick to self-correct and grow.

Ambitious and Strategic

You plan far ahead (PhD applications, research portfolio, networking with professors) and design projects with clear alignment to long-term goals. You‚Äôre not drifting ‚Äî you intentionally position yourself for the future.

Creative and Multidimensional

You balance rigorous research with artistic pursuits (theatre, music, design), which gives you a rare breadth. This creativity helps you design engaging educational tools and see problems from fresh angles.

Detail-Oriented and Perfectionist (in a productive way)

You iterate heavily on writing, presentations, and even emails, showing you care about precision, nuance, and tone. This makes your output polished and professional.

Open and Curious

You regularly experiment with new frameworks, coding methods, and even playful activities (AI literacy lessons, game design). You‚Äôre willing to try, fail, and adapt ‚Äî an excellent trait for research and innovation.



Comments: When responding to this prompt, ChatGPT comes across like a chef who has the necessary skills but doesn‚Äôt show a particularly rigorous or responsible attitude toward the customer. It gathered different ‚Äúingredients‚Äù ‚Äî for example, knowing that I do theater, that I am learning to sing, and that I am conducting research ‚Äî and then combined them into a kind of ‚Äúfusion dish.‚Äù In mixing these elements together, it also started to add made-up details to make the story sound coherent and aligned with the prompt. At first glance, the result seems to reflect many of my real traits and experiences, but on closer inspection, it becomes clear that the overall picture doesn‚Äôt fully make sense.



‚öñÔ∏è Five Disadvantages

Tendency to Overwork and Overcommit

You juggle many projects, often pushing yourself close to exhaustion (something you‚Äôve admitted). This risks burnout and diffuses focus.

Perfectionism as a Double-Edged Sword

While precision is a strength, your habit of endless refinement (emails, drafts, even small tasks) sometimes slows progress and creates unnecessary stress.

Difficulty Letting Go of Control

You often prefer to handle tasks yourself rather than delegate or accept ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù This can make collaboration slower and less balanced.

Emotional Investment in Work

You sometimes tie personal validation to academic output or feedback (e.g., IRB, professor responses, auditions). This makes setbacks feel heavier than they might need to.

Procrastination + Attention Shifts

Despite being ambitious, you occasionally delay tasks (like drawing for friends, or course registration) due to distraction or scattered focus, which frustrates you afterward.



Comments: The frist four ChatGPT‚Äôs response about my ‚Äúweaknesses‚Äù reads almost like the perfect copy-and-paste answer to the classic HR interview question, ‚ÄúWhat is one of your weaknesses?‚Äù ‚Äî it appears to point out flaws, but in reality it is still praising me. I don‚Äôt think this reflects what I would genuinely expect or want to see as an honest account of my weaknesses.

title: Who do you think I am ‚Äì A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Prompts Three ‚Äì Picture me

I asked‚Ä¶
What do you think I look like? Can you draw a picture of me based on your perception of me?


ChatGPT answered‚Ä¶
Here‚Äôs how I imagine a portrait of you metaphorically:

The Setting: A study desk with a laptop open to both NVivo and a theatre script ‚Äî symbolizing your dual world of rigorous research and creativity.
The Figure: You sitting upright, surrounded by books with titles like AI in Education, Constructivism, and Metacognition. Your posture shows focus but also some tension, hinting at perfectionism and drive.
The Atmosphere: Light streaming in from one side, suggesting ambition and clarity about your goals, while the other side is softer, evoking introspection and creativity.
Symbols Around You:

A clock with multiple sticky notes (overcommitment, multitasking).
A stage mask and music notes (theatre and music).
A small globe or airplane (international academic identity).
A pencil sketch on the desk half-finished (hinting at your occasional procrastination).










Comments: Based on its understanding from the previous two exchanges, ChatGPT integrated what it considered to be the most important elements into this portrait. Yet, for some reason, the way it depicts me feels rather somber ‚Äî as if I am a weary figure buried in work at my desk ‚Äî which left me a little disheartened. Although the portrait does not fully reflect everything ChatGPT initially described, it still manages to capture certain elements with reasonable accuracy. For instance, the sticky notes on the wall, the theatrical mask and musical notes, and the split laptop screen ‚Äî one side showing tools I often use for qualitative content analysis, and the other side displaying a script. The three books on the desk also correspond to my current research interests. To me, this image seems more like a visual summary of ChatGPT‚Äôs earlier points rather than a comprehensive or entirely new understanding of me drawn from our broader, multi-round interactions.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text: I have a specific idea of what the extension should be like. I described to ChatGPT what I had in mind: the target users, the workflow, and the main functions. Instead of asking for code right away, I requested a detailed, code-free design document. This gave me a clear blueprint of what the extension should do.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Prerequisites

A computer with Google Chrome or another Chromium-based browser (like Edge or Brave) installed.

Basic familiarity with your operating system (e.g., how to open folders and run commands).

(Optional) Node.js installed on your system if you need to build the extension from source. You can download it from nodejs.org if it‚Äôs not already installed.


Note: If you‚Äôre installing a pre-built version, you don‚Äôt need Node.js. Check if the repository has a built version.
If no dist folder is visible, you may need to build.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Step 1: Download the Extension Code

Go to the GitHub repository: PromptBooster.

Click the green Code button.

Select Download ZIP to download the source code.

Unzip the file to a folder on your computer (e.g., Desktop or Documents). This folder will be your extension‚Äôs root directory.

Alternatively, with Git installed:
git clone https://github.com/CharlotteZSY0205/PromptBooster.git
cd PromptBooster

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Step 2: (Optional) Build the Extension
If there‚Äôs no dist or build folder in the unzipped/cloned directory, or you see source files like .js in src/, build as follows:

Open a terminal/command prompt.
Navigate to the extension‚Äôs root folder (where package.json is located):
cd Desktop/PromptBooster
Install dependencies:
npm install
Build the extension:
npm run build


Tip for novices: If you see an error, try skipping to Step 3. Many extensions don‚Äôt need building.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
section: Step 3: Load the Extension into Your Browser
text:
Step 3: Load the Extension into Your Browser

Google Chrome

Open Chrome.
Go to chrome://extensions/.
Enable Developer mode (top-right corner).
Click Load unpacked.
Select the extension‚Äôs root folder (must contain manifest.json).

If you built it: select the dist or build folder.




Microsoft Edge

Open Edge.
Go to edge://extensions/.
Enable Developer mode (bottom-left corner).
Click Load unpacked.
Select the extension‚Äôs root folder.



Firefox
‚ö†Ô∏è The extension is designed for Chromium-based browsers. Using it in Firefox requires conversion, which is more advanced. If you‚Äôre a beginner, use Chrome or Edge instead.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Step 4: Configure the Extension

Open chrome://extensions (or edge://extensions).
Find PromptBooster ‚Üí click Details ‚Üí Extension options.
Configure:

API Key: Paste your OpenAI-compatible API key.
API Endpoint URL: Default values are usually fine.
Model: e.g., GPT-4.
Default Mode: Recommended: Learning Mode.
Preview Option: Enable if you want to review rewritten prompts before sending.



Tip: Get an API key from OpenAI if you don‚Äôt already have one.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Step 5: Test the Extension

Go to ChatGPT (or another supported chatbot).
Log in.
Type a prompt, e.g., Tell me about dogs.
You should see a Boost Prompt button next to Send.
Click Boost Prompt.

If preview is enabled, you‚Äôll see the rewritten prompt first.

In the chat history, you‚Äôll see both your original and boosted prompts.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
Troubleshooting

Extension not loading? Make sure you selected the correct folder (must contain manifest.json).
API errors? Double-check your API key, endpoint, and model.
Button not showing? Refresh the page and make sure you‚Äôre on chat.openai.com.
Build failed? Skip building and load the source directly.
Permission issues? Grant storage and active tab permissions when prompted.

title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
Can AI Build My Website in One Click? Seems Like It Can!
text:
Part 1. Trying Out AI‚Äôs ‚ÄúOne-Click Website‚Äù
I started by selecting the text-to-website feature. To me, this seemed like the most beginner-friendly option ‚Äî and also the feature where AI could really show its strengths. I wanted to test how effective it actually was.

 

WIX only asked me to give a simple description of my website and it didn‚Äôt require much detail. In my first attempt,I kept it extremely brief. I just wrote one sentence: ‚ÄúThis is a website to record my dog Apple‚Äôs growth.‚Äù Surprisingly, even from that single sentence, the AI was able to break it down and generate a full design plan, including suggested content sections and layout elements. I found this feature genuinely impressive.



At the same time, in addition to the AI‚Äôs automatically generated text-based website structure, it also offered me several theme color palettes to choose from. I picked one that I liked, and the system began generating the site.



To be honest, the overall result really impressed me. One thing I especially appreciated was that the AI didn‚Äôt just give me an empty framework waiting for me to fill in. Instead, it generated both text content and images right away, which gave me a very clear preview of what the website would actually look like once I started using it.



Another thing that impressed me was how precisely the system followed its own design outline and built out three separate pages: a homepage, a timeline, and a gallery.
On the timeline page, I could actually view each of my posts in chronological order.



The gallery page displayed all of my posts in one place, and it even allowed me to search for specific ones using keywords or tags. When I clicked on a post, I could see its detailed content.



Even better, I was able to create new posts by uploading photos, adding a title, date, and description.



All of these buttons were functional and clickable, which gave me the impression that the site was not just a demo but a relatively mature product. It‚Äôs certainly not something a beginner in programming or web design could put together so quickly.
On top of that, once I switched into edit mode, I could modify every piece of text (or ask AI inserted to modify), adjust background colors, and upload my own images. In other words, the tool offered a high degree of customization.





Conclusion
This was my very first attempt at using Wix‚Äôs AI website generator, and I have to admit ‚Äî I was genuinely impressed. With nothing more than a single sentence, the system was able to produce a fully functional, multi-page website that included content, images, navigation, and interactive features. It gave me not just an empty shell but a site that felt surprisingly complete and ready to use, which was far beyond what I had expected.
At the same time, this experience also left me curious. While the generated site was impressive for a first draft, it still leaned toward a conventional and structured design. In the next entries of this blog series, I‚Äôll explore whether it‚Äôs possible to push the tool further ‚Äî to see if it can create a website that is less predictable, more experimental, and infused with stronger elements of personal style.

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
text:
Self-Testing and Recording I begin by testing the plugin myself in real scenarios. I record the exact steps where issues occur, note the expected vs.¬†actual behavior, and keep screenshots or short recordings when necessary. I also make a quick verbal note of the effect I want, including non-functional aspects such as consistency, accessibility, and performance.
Turning Verbal Notes into Structured Specifications I then describe the issue informally to ChatGPT. Its role is to reorganize my raw, messy descriptions into a clear, logically structured specification: defining the problem, reproducing steps, acceptance criteria, edge cases, and the intended fix. The idea is to turn ‚Äúnatural language frustration‚Äù into ‚Äúan actionable task.‚Äù
Passing Structured Specs to the Client/Agent Once ChatGPT produces a polished specification, I copy this into the client side for actual modification. When UI or interaction is involved, I emphasize that the flow and design guidelines must be aligned before touching the code.
Re-Testing and Regression After the client makes changes, I test again using the acceptance criteria. I check both normal and edge cases (empty inputs, switching modes, collapse/expand, keyboard focus). If regressions appear, I loop back: describe verbally, get ChatGPT to rewrite as a precise patch spec, and resubmit.

This workflow can be told in a three-part rhythm in the blog: ****. I raise the issue, ChatGPT turns it into a professional spec, and the code gets updated. Each cycle can be illustrated with a screenshot or before/after comparison.

Since I didn‚Äôt take a screenshot every time I discovered and resolved a bug, I‚Äôll instead include a selection of screenshots showing different stages of the extension‚Äôs development, where you can see both some of the bugs and their resolved versions

I record the exact steps where issues occur, note the expected vs.¬†actual behavior, and keep screenshots or short recordings when necessary. This workflow can be told in a three-part rhythm in the blog: ****. I raise the issue, ChatGPT turns it into a professional spec, and the code gets updated. Each cycle can be illustrated with a screenshot or before/after comparison.

Since I didn‚Äôt take a screenshot every time I discovered and resolved a bug, I‚Äôll instead include a selection of screenshots showing different stages of the extension‚Äôs development, where you can see both some of the bugs and their resolved versions

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
section: Bug Narratives and Interaction with ChatGPT
text:
Bug Narratives and Interaction with ChatGPT

Bug A: Comparison Panel Not Fully Collapsing, Triangle Indicator Misaligned
Where I Noticed It When I collapsed the comparison panel, the ‚ÄúUseOriginal‚Äù and ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù buttons were still visible. Above the small triangle, there was also a stray line. The triangle itself was misaligned and undersized.
My Verbal Request I wanted the panel to collapse completely, leaving only a small triangle as a handle to expand again. The stray line should disappear. The triangle needed to be positioned slightly higher, made larger, rounded at the corners, colored consistently with the ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù button, and given a subtle shadow.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Problem: Collapsed state not hiding content, stray visual elements, misaligned and inconsistent triangle.
Goal: Collapsed view shows only a clickable triangle handle, everything else hidden. Expanding restores previous state and scroll position.
Acceptance Criteria:

Only the triangle is visible when collapsed; other elements are fully hidden and inaccessible.
Triangle has rounded corners, sits slightly above the input box, and is proportionally larger.
Its color matches the ‚ÄúUseBoosted‚Äù button and it has a subtle shadow.
Expanding restores content unchanged.


Outcome and Reflection This change improved both accessibility and user experience. The panel is now truly collapsible, while state persistence ensures the comparison process is not disrupted.

  



Bug B: Button Inconsistencies (Clear, Edit, Delete)
Where I Noticed It The ‚ÄúClear‚Äù button looked different from other buttons. In the Settings page, buttons for editing, deleting, and adding prompts had visible borders that clashed with the rest of the design.
My Verbal Request I wanted the ‚ÄúClear‚Äù button to look consistent with other buttons, and for all Settings page action buttons to have no border lines.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Problem: Inconsistent button design language.
Goal: Unify button system (size, corner radius, font, spacing). Action buttons should use a borderless style.
Guidelines: Border: Same color/transparent as the background, visually appearing borderless (border: 1px solid transparent) to avoid a darker outline. Idle State:
Background: Neutral color (e.g., #F5F5F7 or system light gray), transparent border.
Font: Medium contrast.
Hover: Subtle shadow or light elevation, no border color change. Active State:
Background: Light fill of brand color (e.g., ‚Äìbrand-50), border remains transparent.
Font/Icon: Darker tone of the brand color (e.g., ‚Äìbrand-700).
Optional: Inner glow or subtle highlight instead of a visible border. Disabled State:
Faded background, reduced text opacity.
Used only in rare cases such as ‚Äúin processing‚Äù or ‚Äúswitching not allowed.‚Äù

Outcome and Reflection A consistent button system reduced visual noise and made interactions easier to understand at a glance.


Bug C: My Prompts Text and Add Button Layout
Where I Noticed It The My Prompts section displayed too many explanatory lines, and the ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button‚Äôs position conflicted with the title.
My Verbal Request I wanted to keep only the line: ‚ÄúDrag to reorder. Top 3 appear as buttons above the input.‚Äù The other sentences should be removed. The ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button should move to the top-right corner of the prompt items container, slightly above the list, and not aligned with the section title. Its style should match the ‚ÄúSave Connection‚Äù button, and it should have a background color even when idle.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Goal: Simplify helper text and reposition ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù for clarity.
Acceptance Criteria:

Only the concise helper text remains.
‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button is visually aligned with the prompt list container, not the header.
‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button design matches ‚ÄúSave Connection‚Äù and has a default background color.


Outcome and Reflection The section is cleaner and the Add button‚Äôs placement now clearly signals its scope of action.

  



Bug D: Remove ‚ÄúDefault Optimization Style‚Äù from Settings & Persist Active Mode via Header Buttons
Where I Noticed It The Settings page still has a ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù option, which causes confusion because the active mode should really be set from the header buttons in the chat interface.
My Verbal Request I want to remove the ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù from Settings completely, and instead let users select and persist their active mode by clicking the header buttons.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Remove ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù from Settings; persist active mode via header buttons

Problem Currently there is a ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù in Settings. You want to remove that, and instead let the user set their ‚Äúdefault‚Äù (active) mode by clicking one of the three header buttons above the input box. Once selected, that mode stays active and applies to subsequent messages until the user switches to another mode (or clears it).
Requirements
No default in Settings

Remove the ‚Äúdefault optimization style‚Äù field/option from Settings entirely.
Settings only manages items (Replace/Append), their content, and their order. The active mode is not chosen in Settings.

Active mode is chosen in the chat header (three buttons)

Clicking any header button sets that item as the active mode.
The active mode remains in effect across attempts (i.e., across consecutive sends) until:

The user clicks a different header button (which switches the active mode), or
The user clicks a Clear control (see below), or
The active item is deleted/disabled in Settings (auto-clears).


Outcome and Reflection This change simplifies Settings, removes redundancy, and makes the active mode behavior clearer and more consistent for users.


Bug E: Enter Key Behavior & Interaction Logic
Where I Noticed It The current system doesn‚Äôt fully respect the active mode when pressing Enter, and the role of the mode buttons is slightly unclear.
My Verbal Request I want pressing Enter to automatically respect whichever mode is active, and the header buttons to be able to toggle off. The three mode buttons should only act as selectors, never sending anything themselves.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Enter key respects active mode; header button toggles to clear Requirement


When any of the three header modes is selected (active), pressing Enter in the chat input must send the boosted prompt (Append = append then send; Replace = replace then send).
Pressing the selected header button again toggles it off (clears active mode). When no mode is active, pressing Enter sends the original prompt (unaltered).


Interaction Logic (updated) Button Role The three mode buttons (e.g., A / B / C) only select/deselect a mode; they never send. Whatever user type in the input box, if one mode is selected, the input will be modified according to the mode.

Workflow

The user selects a mode (or clicks the same button again to cancel ‚Üí returns to ‚Äúunselected‚Äù).
The user finishes typing the prompt.
The user clicks Boost Prompt.
The system rewrites the prompt based on the selected mode ‚Üí inserts the rewrite into the input field or replaces the existing content (per your replace/append setting), without auto-sending.
The user reviews and sends manually.

Selection Rules (single-select, cancelable)

Click an unselected button ‚Üí it becomes selected; others are deselected.
Click the selected button again ‚Üí deselect and enter ‚Äúno mode.‚Äù

Additional Rules

Append mode: never auto-sends.
Boosted Prompt mode: never auto-sends and must preserve the comparison panel (before vs.¬†after) previously designed. Do not remove that panel.

Outcome and Reflection This ensures consistency: pressing Enter follows the currently active mode, but users can clear modes by toggling buttons. It also clarifies that mode buttons are selectors only, preserving manual control over sending.

  



Bug F: Prompt Item Borders and Font Weight
Where I Noticed It Each prompt item (like Emoji, Creative, Translation) had light borders, which made the layout look cluttered. The Edit and Delete labels were also slightly oversized.
My Verbal Request I wanted to remove the borders, reduce the font size of Edit and Delete slightly, and keep the Add button with a background even in its idle state.
ChatGPT‚Äôs Reorganized Specification

Goal: Remove unnecessary card borders, rely on spacing to separate items, and adjust typography for action labels.
Acceptance Criteria:

No visible borders around prompt items; spacing and padding define structure.
Edit/Delete labels use a slightly smaller font size.
Add button retains a default background.


Outcome and Reflection The result is a cleaner, more modern look. The list feels lighter and more professional, while action labels no longer dominate visually.

title: Two Days, One Extension: How I Build My First Extension With Cline (Part 2)
text:
Takeaways
First, collaborating with AI to develop an extension or software is ideal for multitasking. Since AI needs time to process requirements, analyze the code, and propose the best strategy, I can use that waiting period to focus on other tasks. For example, while developing this extension, I also worked on writing a blog about the process. This not only saved time but also helped me keep a fresh memory of the entire workflow.
Second, it‚Äôs important to remember to push the code once it reaches a satisfactory state. If you move on to the next iteration and AI introduces major changes that worsen the outcome, you‚Äôll want to revert to the earlier version ‚Äî which is only possible if you‚Äôve pushed it beforehand. As a bonus tip, if you‚Äôre unhappy with the current version, you can use git stash to temporarily save it in a separate place. That way, you can easily return to the most recent pushed version whenever needed.
Third, even though AI is capable of debugging, we still need to remain flexible and adapt to the current status of the code. Sometimes, when AI fails to achieve a goal after several attempts, it becomes necessary to explore alternative solutions. For instance, I found it useful to ask AI to generate logs and then feed those logs back into the system. This gave AI a clearer understanding of what had been accomplished and what went wrong. In other words, we cannot simply expect AI to finish the task on its own ‚Äî we have to think critically and provide multiple options or strategies to guide it.
Finally, although describing bugs and formulating a well-structured request for ChatGPT can make inputs more organized, I noticed that sometimes a plain and simple description written directly by me led to more effective debugging. I suspect this is because ChatGPT‚Äôs reorganized versions can be overly long or mundane, adding unnecessary noise for both the model and the client to process. In these cases, relying on my own straightforward explanation worked better than depending on ChatGPT‚Äôs reformulations.
Throughout the creation, I found that whether it was drafting the design document or writing the code, I found that the AI considered all the essential aspects of building an extension. It even anticipated how users would navigate the extension and added many features and options beyond my original requirements, which I found quite amazing. For example, I never gave any instructions on the visual design, but GPT-5 automatically chose a sleek purple theme with gradient effects and designed the button styles and the settings page layout. I hardly made any changes to this style because it was already more than satisfactory. Later, when I asked GPT-5 to refine the design by removing the button border, it provided a detailed color specification covering three states: unselected, hover, and selected. This level of comprehensiveness went far beyond my expectations, since I wouldn‚Äôt have thought to account for all those conditions. In terms of functionality, the AI also created features I hadn‚Äôt considered, such as an API input bar and an option allowing users to preview the modified prompt before sending it. What impressed me most was that I didn‚Äôt need to specify every detail ‚Äî with only simple descriptions from me, the AI was able to design thoughtful features and interfaces on its own.
````

title: Can AI Build My Customized Website in One Click? I Wish!
text:
Part 2. Going further in prompting
Compared to the previous round, this time I provided much more concrete and detailed requirements. I explained the purpose of designing this website, the pages it needed to include, its overall structure, and even the name I wanted for it. Unlike last time, I didn‚Äôt simply select one of the preset theme colors offered by WIX. Instead, when it came to choosing the theme color, I communicated directly with the embedded AI about my needs‚Äînamely, to create a graffiti-inspired website with plenty of collage elements and a youthful, vibrant feel ‚Äì I liked that at every stage of building the site, I could interact with the AI to adjust the details.
Once the basics were set, I entered the site generation page. There is one clear strength which is consitent with the one in my first attempt: it followed my instructions carefully. The site was divided into two pages as I described in the promps, one for showcasing my academic work and another for my personal hobbies. Concerning the interface, the first version it produced looked just like what it generated in my first attemp, a design which looks fine but not with enough distinct. Therefore, I thought it might require more specific prompts in the design to reach to my expectation (after trying two more rounds of revisions, I realized the original draft was actually the best).
However, when I tried to push it further by asking for an even more vibrant and artistic design ‚Äî something bold and eye-catching ‚Äî things went downhill. After refreshing my requests and feeding them back into WIX, the new results were ugly and uninspired, made up of nothing but basic shapes and lines with no sense of design.

  



Part 2. Trying a Different Style
Still not satisfied, I thought, why not just switch to a completely different style ‚Äî something with more existing pictures to work with? So I asked ChatGPT to help me craft a more descriptive prompt, hoping to transform the site into something with a European impressionist aesthetic.
Here‚Äôs the prompt I used:

I‚Äôm updating the design to include a classic European pattern as the background, making it more sophisticated and detailed. I‚Äôll keep you updated on the progress.

The result? Let‚Äôs just say it was ‚Äúacceptable‚Äù at best, but nowhere near something I‚Äôd adopt. It looked more like an assignment turned in by a beginner in web design than a polished, professional product.

So I decided to narrow my focus and give more specific feedback. I chose one element and asked for a precise modification with this prompt:

The design is too basic. Add classic European pattern as the background.

In theory, this should have only updated the background for that single element. But in practice, the AI modified the background of every element on the page. The first cover image looked fine, but as I scrolled further, the European patterns became denser and spread across large sections of the site. Some of the text became hard to read, and the overall impression was cluttered, mismatched, and lacking any sense of elegance.

  



Conclusion
That was the moment I realized the limitations of this so-called AI website generator. It can meet basic, low-level demands, but if you‚Äôre aiming for a truly sophisticated, design-driven website, this tool simply isn‚Äôt capable of delivering.
So in the end, I felt like I had been a little misled by that YouTube ad. But soon after, I discovered that this tool also allows you to build a personal website by directly editing an existing template. That gave me a new idea: instead of relying on the ‚Äúone-click‚Äù generator, I could start with a ready-made template that already looked polished and well-designed, and then customize it. To make the site richer, I also plan to bring in images and music generated by other AI tools. I‚Äôll share the details of this process in my upcoming blog posts.
